msItem.note: This description is abbreviated from Daniela Mairhofer, Medieval Manuscripts from Würzburg in the Bodleian Library, Oxford: A Descriptive Catalogue (Oxford, 2014), pp. 487–514. For purposes of scholarly citation, reference to the printed catalogue is requested.

msItem.title: Homiliary
msItem.note: The present compilation of homilies from the Fathers not known from other manuscripts; all identifiable (as indicated below), many from the Homiliarius doctorum often ascribed to Paul the Deacon, in most cases however considerably shortened. Feasts often indicated at the beginning of a text.

(fol. 2ra) Temporale, beginning with Christmas Eve and including the Purification (2 February); (fol. 134rb) principal feasts of the Sanctorale after Pentecost; (fol. 177vb) homily in nativitate BMV (impf.; between fols 177/178 (quires xxiv & xxv), one or more quires went probably missing, before the foliation was inserted); (fol. 178ra) Advent. (fol. 198va) Additional homilies for the Sundays from Septuagesima to Passiontide, (fol. 216vb) the homily In passione dni, end impf.; (fol. 217ra) passion of St Juliana (16 February), impf.
Eight leaves missing at the beginning, see the 15th-cent. foliation.
List of contents, on an added fifteenth-century leaf (bifolium, counterpart cancelled, fol. iii glued to the stub).
Fer. 4 post dncam 1 post epiph. dni
Fer. 4 post dncam 2 post epiph. dni
Gregory the Great, Homiliae XL in evangelia, hom. 2. 22
Dnca pentecostes et de spiritu sancto
Ps.-Bede, Commentary on John, cap. 3. Here ascribed to Augustine.
Ps.-Bede, Commentary on John, cap. 10. Here ascribed to Augustine.
Ps.-Bede, Commentary on John, cap. 6. Here ascribed to Augustine.
Gregory the Great, Homiliae XL in evangelia, 2. 40
Gregory the Great, Homiliae XL in evangelia, 2. 39
Augustine, De sermone domini in monte 2. 14. 47–15. 50
Paul the Deacon, Homiliarius 2.90. Here ascribed to Augustine.
Gregory the Great, Homiliae XL in evangelia, 2. 38
Gregory the Great, Homiliae XL in evangelia, 2. 28
In vigilia s. Petri et Pauli
Paul the Deacon, Homiliarius 2.54. Here ascribed to Bede.
Paul the Deacon, Homiliarius 2.124. Here ascribed to Bede.
Gregory the Great, Homiliae XL in evangelia, 2. 33
Paul the Deacon, Homiliarius 2.68. Here ascribed to Bede.
Ps.-Maximus of Turin, serm. 12 (= Ps.-Ildefonsus of Toledo, serm. 7)
Bede, Commentary on Luke, 6. 22:24–27 (= Ps.-Bede, Homiliae evangelii, hom. 3. 60)
Hrabanus Maurus, Commentary on Matthew 1. 1:1–1:2, imperfect. Here ascribed to Bede.
One or several quires went missing between fols 177/178 (= quires xxiv & xxv), some time between the late 12th and the 15th century (before the foliation was added).

Letter, 1172–1180: the Dean and Chapter of Würzburg Cathedral, under Dean P(ersius), communicate their position regarding the appeal of a certain canon S(igiloh) to the Cathedral Chapter of Mainz (Johanek, Brief, ed. at pp. 33–34). Inserted by a single hand.
Leo the Great, Tractatus septem et nonaginta (= Sermones), tract. 53

Between fols 214/215 two bifolia missing, lost some time after the 15th-cent. foliation was inserted. As suggested by the entry in the index (fol. 1vd), one or more sermons In passione dni are missing.

supportDesc.extent: i (modern paper) + i (17th-cent. paper) + 1 (15th-cent. parchment) + 220 + 1 (15th cent. parchment) + i (modern paper), foliated i-iii, 1–222. c. 400–11 310–15 (trimmed)

layoutDesc.layout: 2 cols. of mostly 25–31 lines (fol. 1, 4 columns of 35 lines). Ruled space c. 290–310 204–18

binding.p: Brown tanned calf over laminated pulpboard for Abp. Laud, 1637–1639.

accMat.p: (fol. 221r–v) fragment of Huguccio of Pisa, Derivationes, s. xv2; part of a bifolium, probably the lower pastedown of an earlier binding.

history.provenance: Written at Würzburg, Domstift St Kilian, to judge by the inclusion of the Passio s. Kiliani, and also the inserted letter on fol. 198ra–rb.

Würzburg, Domstift St Kilian, 15th century: the 15th-cent. foliation consisting of black roman numerals is identical in style with that of MS. Laud Misc. 157, which has an ex-libris inscription of the Domstift on fol. 227v.
William Laud, 1573–1645: his ex libris, 1636, fol. 1r.
history.acquisition: Given to the Bodleian as part of his third donation, dispatched on 28 June 1639.

recordHist.source: See above. Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (H. O. Coxe, Laudian Manuscripts, Quarto Catalogues II, repr. with corrections, 1969, from the original ed. of 1858–1885). Quarto Catalogue, col. 146 Quarto Catalogue, p. 549 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 38

ref.title: Manuscripts from German-Speaking Lands – A Polonsky Foundation Digitization Project

listBibl.bibl: Otto Pächt and J. J. G. Alexander, Illuminated Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library, Oxford, I (1966), no. 89

revisionDesc.change: Description revised for Polonsky digitization project to include additional information from Mairhofer catalogue.
